results.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Michael Schwirtz and Eric Schmitt
results.title: Leaked Documents Reveal Depth of U.S. Spy Efforts and Russia’s Military Struggles
results.abstract: The information, exposed on social media sites, also shows that U.S. intelligence services are eavesdropping on important allies.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

media.caption: The new documents appear to show that America’s understanding of Russian planning remains extensive and that the United States is able to warn Ukraine’s military about Moscow’s future operations.

results.adx_keywords: Railroads;Travel and Vacations;Food;Central Europe;Czech Republic;Zurich (Switzerland);Vienna (Austria)
results.title: Dining in Style, at 90 Miles an Hour
results.abstract: Train travel is thriving in Central Europe, and so are dining cars. We rode the rails from Prague to Zurich and beyond, sampling regional dishes and savoring the views.

media.caption: Passengers on Switzerland’s Rhaetian Railway may dine on regional dishes in the Gourmino dining car as the Swiss countryside slips by.
media.copyright: Clara Tuma for The New York Times

results.title: At 81, Ann-Margret Is Finally Living Her Rock ’n’ Roll Dream
results.abstract: The actress and musician, who first burst out in “Bye Bye Birdie” in 1963, is releasing a new album of old rock covers featuring guests like her “Tommy” co-star Pete Townshend.

media.caption: Ann-Margret’s new album, “Born to Be Wild,” includes a cover of the Steppenwolf title song along with other rock classics.
media.copyright: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times

results.title: A Visit to the Peeps Factory
results.abstract: As Easter approached, The New York Times for Kids took a trip to a world of marshmallow magic.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Nuremberg War Crimes Tribunal (1945-49);Holocaust and the Nazi Era;World War II (1939-45);War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity;Ferencz, Benjamin B;International Criminal Court
results.title: Benjamin B. Ferencz, Last Surviving Nuremberg Prosecutor, Dies at 103
results.abstract: In addition to convicting prominent Nazi war criminals, he crusaded for an international criminal court and for laws to end wars of aggression.
des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

media.caption: Benjamin B. Ferencz, right, at the signing of an agreement between West Germany and Israel in Luxembourg in 1952. Mr. Ferencz helped Jewish groups negotiate a reparations settlement under which West Germany agreed to pay $822 million to Israel and to groups representing survivors of Nazi persecution.

results.adx_keywords: Snakes;Pilots;Airlines and Airplanes;South Africa
results.title: A Cobra Appeared Mid-Flight. The Pilot’s Quick Thinking Saved Lives.
results.abstract: The pilot made an emergency landing after feeling a Cape Cobra slither under his shirt while flying across South Africa. “I had a moment of stunned silence,” he said.

media.caption: The plane that was piloted by Rudolf Erasmus being searched at the Welkom Airport, in Welkom, South Africa, for the Cape Cobra snake that was spotted during a flight.

results.adx_keywords: Global Warming;Greenhouse Gas Emissions;Automobiles;Electric and Hybrid Vehicles;Regulation and Deregulation of Industry;Fuel Emissions (Transportation);Air Pollution;Biden, Joseph R Jr;Environmental Protection Agency
results.title: E.P.A. Is Said to Propose Rules Meant to Drive Up Electric Car Sales Tenfold
results.abstract: In what would be the nation’s most ambitious climate regulation, the proposal is designed to ensure that electric cars make up the majority of new U.S. auto sales by 2032.

media.caption: President Biden delivered a speech at a General Motors electric vehicle assembly plant in Detroit in 2021. The new rules would exceed his earlier goal that half the cars sold in the United States be all-electric by 2030.

results.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Steven Lee Myers
results.title: Can We No Longer Believe Anything We See?
results.abstract: Human eyes — and even technology — often struggle to identify images created by artificial intelligence. Experts fear that may hasten an erosion of trust in media, in government and in society.

media.caption: This image of four people walking down a street, created by Andrés Guadamuz, looks like a standard snapshot.

results.adx_keywords: Easter and Holy Week;Protestant Churches;Christians and Christianity;Jesus Christ
results.title: On Hope, Hate and the Most Radical Claim of the Easter Season
results.abstract: Hope pulls you out of yourself and into the world, forcing you to believe more is possible. Hate is a much less insistent master.

media.copyright: Kevin Liles for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Happiness;Optimism;Politics and Government;Badminton;vis-photo;Finland
results.byline: By Penelope Colston and Jake Michaels
results.title: The Finnish Secret to Happiness? Knowing When You Have Enough.
results.abstract: The Nordic nation has been ranked the happiest country on earth for six consecutive years. But when you talk to individual Finns, the reality is a bit more complicated.

media.caption: Henna and Niklas Hukari, siblings who play badminton in the rural community of Toholampi, are among more than a dozen Finns we spoke with about how optimism manifests in their lives.
media.copyright: Jake Michaels for The New York Times

results.title: The Essential Gabriel García Márquez
results.abstract: The Colombian novelist mixed fiction and fact to capture the outsize reality of Latin America. Even if you’ve never watched a priest levitate, a carpet fly or a drop of blood climb over curbs, there’s something for you.
